image.altText: Julius Jungerth

props.synopsis: Hundreds of coin collectors forwent the late-night revelry of New Year's Eve in favour of an early morning visit to the Royal Australian Mint in Canberra, hoping to get their hands on the highly sought-after first coin of the year.

title.children: New coin celebrates 60 years of decimal currency

image.altText: Two people shopping in a homewares store.

props.synopsis: Outlet centres around Australia were bustling on Boxing Day, but just down the road, some small retailers were feeling the sting. It's a trend that could shape the future of the Boxing Day sales.

title.children: 'We won't survive': Small retailers missing out on Boxing Day sales

image.altText: A person holding a mobile phone scrolling Facebook Marketplace.

props.synopsis: Savannah thought she had taken all the right steps to protect herself while selling items on Facebook Marketplace — but that did not stop her from being scammed. Here is what you need to know when buying and selling via online marketplaces.

title.children: Facebook Marketplace and Gumtree are full of scammers. Here is how to avoid them

image.altText: A person scrapes bees from a board with a comb.

props.synopsis: A fast-spreading parasite is expected to devastate local bee colonies over the next two years, affecting commercial and backyard crops.

title.children: Half of Canberra's beehives could be wiped out in two years. Here's why

image.altText: helicopter hovering and emergency crews on a bush track

props.synopsis: Swift-acting bushwalkers and emergency crews "absolutely" saved a woman bitten twice by an eastern brown snake as she hiked on the NSW south coast.

title.children: 'Incredibly lucky' bushwalker survives bites from giant brown snake

image.altText: A man works at his desk using video editing software

props.synopsis: Would those classic black-and-white films be the same if viewed in full colour?

title.children: Debate about colouring old films is not black and white

image.altText: Close up of ladybugs

props.synopsis: When politicians and most staff are away for the summer holidays, a ravenous group of fly-in workers descend on Parliament House.

title.children: The 'voracious feeders' inside Parliament House

image.altText: Reading 5

props.synopsis: There are books from authors that would become household names — F. Scott Fitzgerald and A.A Milne among them — and books that are now banned in some countries. But what can we learn from what people were reading in 1925?

title.children: What a 1925 summer reading list reveals about us

image.altText: camilla sits with two people

props.synopsis: The monarch speaks publicly about the attack for the first time during an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

title.children: Camilla recalls being 'furious' after being indecently assaulted as a teen

image.altText: A police mug shot of a woman.

props.synopsis: Jean Lee and her two co-accused were executed for murder in 1950. Handwritten letters from the trio are among items publicly available for the first time since their trial captured the nation's attention.

title.children: Case file of last woman hanged in Australia released after 75 years

image.altText: Lauren Boebert speaks at a conference.

props.synopsis: A month after Donald Trump's spectacular falling-out with MAGA firebrand Marjorie Taylor Greene, another Republican congresswoman publicly lashes out at the US president.

title.children: Trump clashes with another Republican congresswoman

image.altText: A photo of Emmanuel Macron from the side, wearing a serious expression

props.synopsis: President Emmanual Macron's government will soon submit draft legislation banning children under 15 from using social media, according to French media.

title.children: France reportedly planning social media ban for under-15s

image.altText: A man in combat uniform lying down, and holding a cigarette in one hand.

props.synopsis: Russell Allan Wilson, who spent several years fighting for Ukraine, has been remembered as someone who "gave his life so others could keep theirs".

title.children: Australian soldier fighting for Ukraine 'killed week before wedding'

image.altText: A Palestinian carries a box of food from the World Food Program with a group of other men.

props.synopsis: The Israeli government says the organisations have not met new requirements, which include recognising Israel as a Jewish and democratic state and banning any so-called "de-legitimisation" of Israel.

title.children: 'Simply unprecedented': Israel banning dozens of charities from Gaza

image.altText: A man wearing a helmet while looking out the door of a helicopter which is flying over tsuanmi-devastated land

props.synopsis: From expectations of a trade union backlash against controversial industrial relations reform, to concerns about "homegrown" extremism in Australia, here are what previously unseen cabinet documents tell us about Australian politics in 2005.

title.children: Cabinet papers offer insight into reforms that proved politically fatal for John Howard

image.altText: A US fighter jet flies over a tropical island.

props.synopsis: US military forces have carried out strikes against three boats in international waters in the Pacific Ocean. Eight people are reported to have survived.

title.children: US attacks 'narco-trafficking' boats in international waters

image.altText: A holiday snap of Jo Needham holding a takeaway coffee cup on a train travelling past scenery.

props.synopsis: Jo Needham was halfway through a "bucket list" trip across South America when she was flung from her seat on a train near the ancient tourist site of Machu Picchu.

title.children: Gold Coast woman recounts Machu Picchu train crash

image.altText: Pat Cummins moves to high-10 fellow Australia bowler Josh Hazlewood during the ODI Cricket World Cup.

props.synopsis: Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood and Tim David are all included in Australia's 15-player squad for next month's men's Twenty20 World Cup in Sri Lanka and India.

title.children: Injury-hit trio named in Australia's squad for T20 World Cup

image.altText: Flames and an orange glow from a bushfire emerge over houses and trees at night.

props.synopsis: Police charge a man who allegedly threw a firecracker and sparked an emergency-level bushfire in the Perth Hills that left thousands of people without power and threatened lives and homes.

title.children: 'We had to get out': New Year's Day fire forces residents to flee homes

image.altText: A man and a woman bump bellies together.

props.synopsis: When Lorin Clarke asked her father, satirist John Clarke, if she could start recording their conversations, she thought it would just be for them. But when he tragically died aged 68, one year after the recordings began, Lorin felt his story belonged to more than just her.

title.children: Lorin's father John Clarke had a story to tell, so she recorded their conversations

image.altText: A large crowds gathered around a stage with pyrotechnics at a music festival.

props.synopsis: A pill testing trial has been expanded to Sydney's Field Day music festival, but authorities are urging partygoers not to be complacent.

title.children: Drug warning as revellers head to NYD Sydney music festival

image.altText: aerial drone shot of floodwaters cutting off dirt road, car parked at edge of water

props.synopsis: Outback towns remain cut off, and floodwaters are expected to linger in the north-west for weeks. Graziers have started to assess their properties and count stock losses.

title.children: Stranded travellers welcome new year in the bush as floods cut roads

image.altText: A woman floating in water at a beach.

props.synopsis: Half a century after the first nude beach opened in Australia, these naturists say they are still fighting to keep beaches open and misconceptions at bay.

title.children: Stripping away misconceptions and fighting for nude beaches

image.altText: Two fish under water.

props.synopsis: The Bloomfield River cod, found in a far north Queensland river catchment, is the world's only tropical freshwater cod, and scientists are working to have it officially protected amid threats from the climate and introduced species.

title.children: Scientists rush to protect rare Australian fish species

image.altText: Central Coast Mariners' Matt Simon shouts during a tunnel confrontation with the Brisbane Roar during an A-League match.

props.synopsis: The fallout from Brisbane Roar's spiteful A-League clash with Central Coast continues, with the Roar "considering all options" after comments from Mariners coach Warren Moon following a send-off for Brisbane coach Michael Valkanis that prompted a half-time confrontation in Gosford.

title.children: Roar consider 'all options' over Mariners' comments after NYE clash

image.altText: A close up of a Māori man, black hair, tanned, beard stubble, wearing black singlet as he looks out on the ocean.

props.synopsis: Shalom Kaa used to think running was something other people did. But after a series of events that left him at his lowest, running became a big part of his recovery following years of substance abuse with crystal methamphetamines.

title.children: How running helped Shalom overcome years of substance abuse

image.altText: A police crime scene.

props.synopsis: Two men were taken to hospital with serious injuries after being stabbed in Carlton shortly before midnight.

title.children: Police investigate Melbourne NYE double stabbing

image.altText: A close up shot of blue and white police tape at night.

props.synopsis: A man and a woman will face court charged with numerous offences, including manufacturing unauthorised explosive devices.

title.children: Police find explosives, arrest two people in Bendigo suburb

image.altText: person beside a giant plant, more than a meter in height, inside a conservatorium.

props.synopsis: Renowned for their size and stench, blooming corpse flowers are a rare occurrence. But to have four flowering in a week is "something of a record".

title.children: Four stinky corpse flowers to bloom in a week at Queensland botanic gardens

image.altText: A medium shot of four men next to a white ute in front of a boat

props.synopsis: From today, commercial demersal fishing is banned along hundreds of kilometres of the WA coastline in an effort to recover fish species numbers.

title.children: Permanent fishing ban begins along WA coast as commercial fishers face uncertainty

image.altText: A woman gestures as she speaks into a microphone at a lectern

props.synopsis: There are just two toilets for women near the main hall in Japan's parliament, with nearly 60 MPs calling for changes to the building to match growing female representation.

title.children: Female MPs in Japan want more toilets in parliament

image.altText: Adelaide Strikers batter Chris Lynn looks over his shoulder after a shot in a Big Bash League game against Brisbane Heat.

props.synopsis: Former Brisbane star Chris Lynn clobbers the Adelaide Strikers to an easy victory over the Heat in the New Year's Eve Big Bash League clash.

title.children: Lynn's fireworks get Strikers over the line in NYE clash for first time since 2018

image.altText: Cricket commentator Alex Hartley wears a white sleeveless top.

props.synopsis: Alex Hartley says she was stunned by the reaction to her talking about her period during the BBC's radio commentary of the third Ashes Test.

title.children: Calls for critics to 'grow up' after outcry over period mention on BBC

image.altText: Men walk in front of people standing on a footpath giving them roses

props.synopsis: The release is a key part of a ceasefire deal struck to bring peace to the border between the two countries.

title.children: 'I am so happy': Crowd celebrates Thailand's release of Cambodian soldiers

image.altText: A man sitting on a 95-year-old harvester.

props.synopsis: While most farmers search for the newest technology to help with harvest, Leigh Baker has worked to bring a 95-year-old piece of equipment back to life.

title.children: Farmer restores 95-year-old vintage harvester and puts it to work
